**Why It Matters:** Go-live generates concentrated support demand. Pre-planned support model ensures issues are resolved quickly, maintaining user confidence and adoption.

# Go-Live Support Model - Guidance

**How It Works:** Define support channels (chat, email, phone, in-person). Staff appropriately for expected volume. Train support staff on common issues. Establish escalation paths. Monitor issue patterns and adjust.

**Example:** Hypercare model: Week 1 - dedicated Slack channel with 5-min response SLA, extended hours coverage, daily stand-up to review issues. Week 2-4 - Standard support with escalation path. Week 5+ - Normal operations.

**Best Practices:**
- Plan support model before go-live
- Staff for peak volume in week 1
- Train support on common issues
- Monitor patterns and adjust
- Transition gracefully to steady state

**Watch Out For:**
- Underestimating support volume
- Support staff not prepared
- Escalation bottlenecks
- Abrupt transition to normal support

# SEC Clawback Rule 10D-1

**Definition:** SEC rule requiring public companies to recover erroneously awarded incentive compensation from executive officers following accounting restatements.
**Also known as:** SEC clawback, Dodd-Frank clawback, 10D-1

**Why It Matters:** Public companies must have compliant clawback policies. Rule is 'no-fault' - recovery required regardless of executive misconduct.

# SEC Clawback Rule 10D-1 - Guidance


**Example:** Company restates revenue downward. CFO's bonus was calculated on original revenue. Company must recover excess bonus received in prior 3 fiscal years based on restated financials.

**Best Practices:**
- Adopt compliant clawback policy
- Document recovery procedures
- Calculate recovery amounts accurately
- Coordinate with exchange listing requirements

**Watch Out For:**
- No-fault recovery regardless of misconduct
- Applies to all incentive-based compensation
- Complex calculation requirements
- Disclosure requirements

# SEC Clawback Rule 10D-1 - Regulatory Information

**Legal Basis:** Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform Act Section 954, SEC Rule 10D-1, Exchange listing standards.

**Requirements:**
- Policy must cover all current and former executive officers
- 3-year lookback from restatement date
- No-fault recovery required
- Limited exceptions for enforcement cost vs recovery

**Penalties:** Exchange delisting for non-compliant policy. SEC enforcement.

# Historical Plan Analysis

**Definition:** Analysis of how proposed plan changes would have affected payouts if applied to historical performance data, validating design decisions.
**Also known as:** plan retrospective, historical payout analysis

**Why It Matters:** Historical analysis tests plan changes against real data, revealing unintended consequences before implementation. It's more reliable than projections based on assumptions.

# Historical Plan Analysis - Guidance

**How It Works:** Apply proposed plan rules to historical transactions. Compare new payouts to actual historical payouts. Analyze winners, losers, and aggregate cost. Identify edge cases and anomalies.

**Example:** Proposed change: Raise accelerator threshold from 100% to 110%. Historical analysis shows: 40% fewer reps would have earned accelerators, $2M cost savings, but top 10% would have earned $500K less - retention risk.

**Best Practices:**
- Use multiple years of history
- Analyze by segment and cohort
- Identify winners and losers
- Consider behavioral changes
- Document assumptions and limitations

**Watch Out For:**
- Past performance may not predict future
- Behavioral changes not captured
- Data quality in historical periods
- Changed business context

# BI Tool Integration

**Definition:** Integration between compensation systems and business intelligence platforms for advanced visualization and cross-functional analytics.
**Also known as:** Tableau integration, Power BI, Looker integration

**Why It Matters:** BI integration enables compensation data to be analyzed alongside sales, finance, and HR data for enterprise insights beyond what ICM systems provide natively.

# BI Tool Integration - Guidance

**How It Works:** Export compensation data to data warehouse. BI tool connects to warehouse. Analysts build dashboards combining comp with other data sources. Self-service enables ad-hoc analysis.

**Example:** Tableau dashboard: Comp earnings by rep overlaid with CRM activity metrics, showing correlation between call volume and commission attainment. Finance uses for cost center analysis.

**Best Practices:**
- Define data model for analytics
- Secure sensitive compensation data
- Create reusable data sets
- Train analysts on comp data nuances
- Maintain data freshness

**Watch Out For:**
- Compensation data sensitivity
- Data freshness delays
- Metric definition consistency
- Analyst interpretation errors

# BI Tool Integration - Vendor Terminology

**Vendor Terminology:**
- **Generic:** BI Integration

# Compensation Microlearning

**Definition:** Training approach using short, focused learning modules (2-5 minutes) that users consume on-demand for specific tasks or concepts.
**Also known as:** bite-sized learning, just-in-time training, micro-training

**Why It Matters:** Adult learners retain more from short, focused modules than long training sessions. Microlearning enables just-in-time learning when users need specific knowledge.

# Compensation Microlearning - Guidance

**How It Works:** Break content into focused micro-modules. Make accessible on-demand (mobile, desktop). Target specific tasks or concepts. Track completion and comprehension. Recommend based on role and need.

**Example:** Microlearning library: 'How to read your statement' (3 min), 'Understanding accelerators' (2 min), 'Disputing a calculation' (4 min). Rep accesses when needed from statement portal.

**Best Practices:**
- Keep modules under 5 minutes
- Focus each on single concept or task
- Make easily searchable and accessible
- Track usage to identify gaps
- Update content regularly

**Watch Out For:**
- Fragmentation without coherence
- Missing foundational context
- Maintenance burden
- Discoverability challenges

# Statute of Limitations

**Definition:** Legal time limits within which compensation claims must be filed, varying by claim type and jurisdiction.
**Also known as:** limitations period, time limits, filing deadlines

**Why It Matters:** Understanding limitations periods helps manage risk exposure and informs record retention. Expired claims may be defensible on limitations grounds.

# Statute of Limitations - Guidance


**Best Practices:**
- Track claim dates and applicable periods
- Retain records through limitations period
- Consult legal for limitations analysis
- Raise limitations defense timely

**Watch Out For:**
- Different periods for different claims
- Discovery rule extends some periods
- State variations
- Tolling for continuing violations

# Statute of Limitations - Regulatory Information

**Legal Basis:** FLSA (2-3 years), State wage claims (varies by state), Breach of contract (state law, often 4-6 years), Fraud claims (discovery rule may extend).

**Requirements:**
- FLSA: 2 years (3 for willful)
- California: 3 years for wage claims
- Breach of contract: State dependent
- Discovery rule may toll limitations

**Penalties:** Claims outside limitations may be barred. But limitations is affirmative defense that must be raised.

# Cognitive Load in Plan Design

**Definition:** The mental effort required to understand and act on compensation plan mechanics, which when excessive reduces plan effectiveness.
**Also known as:** mental complexity, plan complexity, cognitive burden

**Why It Matters:** Plans that are too complex to understand don't influence behavior. Reducing cognitive load improves line of sight and behavioral impact.

# Cognitive Load in Plan Design - Guidance

**How It Works:** Cognitive load comes from: number of measures, calculation complexity, exception rules, period interactions. Reducing load: fewer measures, clearer mechanics, better visualization, simpler language.

**Example:** High cognitive load: 5 measures with weighted gates, quarterly resets, holdbacks, and retroactive adjustments. Low cognitive load: 2 measures, simple accelerators, clear statements.

**Best Practices:**
- Test plan explanation with actual reps
- Limit measures and interactions
- Use clear, simple language
- Provide calculation examples
- Design intuitive statements

**Watch Out For:**
- Complexity justified by 'fairness'
- Finance-driven complexity
- Historical baggage
- Exception accumulation

# Calculation Audit Trail

**Definition:** Detailed logging of calculation inputs, logic applied, and outputs for each commission calculation, enabling drill-down and verification.
**Also known as:** calc audit, calculation trace, comp audit log

**Why It Matters:** When reps question calculations, you need to show exactly how the number was derived. Calculation audit trails enable fast dispute resolution and SOX compliance.

# Calculation Audit Trail - Guidance

**How It Works:** Capture for each calculation: Inputs (transactions, quotas, rates), Logic applied (rules, rates, adjustments), Intermediate steps, Final output. Store with calculation run ID. Enable drill-down from statement to detail.

**Example:** Statement shows $5,234 commission. Drill-down: 12 credited transactions ($523,400 total) × 1% base rate = $5,234. Each transaction links to source with crediting logic applied.

**Best Practices:**
- Log all calculation inputs and outputs
- Capture rule versions applied
- Enable drill-down from any result
- Retain per audit requirements
- Make accessible to support staff

**Watch Out For:**
- Storage growth from detailed logging
- Performance impact of logging
- Incomplete audit coverage
- Inaccessible audit data

# Iconixx

**Definition:** An enterprise incentive compensation management platform known for flexibility in handling complex compensation scenarios.
**Also known as:** Iconixx ICM

**Why It Matters:** Iconixx serves mid-market and enterprise organizations needing sophisticated plan configurations with strong implementation support.

# Iconixx - Guidance

**How It Works:** Rules-based engine enables complex calculations. Configurable workflows handle approvals. Reporting and analytics provide visibility. Integration framework connects to enterprise systems.

**Best Practices:**
- Leverage rules engine for complex logic
- Document configuration decisions
- Use workflow for approvals
- Test thoroughly before production

**Watch Out For:**
- Complex configurations need documentation
- Training requirements for administrators
- Integration complexity with legacy systems

# beqom

**Definition:** A total compensation cloud platform covering sales incentives, executive compensation, and total rewards management.
**Also known as:** beqom compensation

**Why It Matters:** beqom provides an integrated view across all compensation types, enabling consistent pay philosophy across sales, executive, and broad-based populations.

# beqom - Guidance

**How It Works:** Unified platform manages multiple compensation programs. Rules engine handles calculations. Integration with HCM and finance systems. Analytics across compensation types.

**Best Practices:**
- Leverage total rewards integration
- Consider executive comp alongside sales
- Use unified analytics for philosophy alignment

**Watch Out For:**
- Broad scope may exceed sales-specific needs
- Implementation complexity for full suite
- Pricing for full platform

# Caps vs Decelerators

**Definition:** Two approaches to limiting extreme payouts: hard caps that stop earnings at a threshold, or decelerators that reduce but don't eliminate earning above threshold.
**Also known as:** payout limits, cap alternatives

**Why It Matters:** Caps create hard stops that can demotivate top performers. Decelerators maintain motivation while controlling cost, but are more complex to model.

# Caps vs Decelerators - Guidance

**How It Works:** Cap: Earnings stop at 200% of target. Decelerator: Rate reduces from 2x to 1x above 150%, continuing to earn at reduced rate. Both limit cost but with different behavioral effects.

**Example:** Rep at 200% of quota: With cap at 200%, earns exactly 200% of target. With decelerator from 150%, earns 150% at 2x rate + 50% at 1x rate = 200% of target. Same cost, but decelerator maintains motivation.

**Best Practices:**
- Prefer decelerators to hard caps
- Set caps high enough to be rare
- Model both approaches before deciding
- Communicate limits transparently

**Watch Out For:**
- Caps hit during windfall create frustration
- Decelerators add complexity
- Either approach needs modeling
- Consider competitive implications

# SPIF Design Principles

**Definition:** Best practices for designing Sales Performance Incentive Funds (SPIFs) that drive specific behaviors without undermining base plan effectiveness.
**Also known as:** SPIF best practices, contest design

**Why It Matters:** SPIFs can focus attention on strategic priorities but poorly designed SPIFs distort behavior, game the system, or undermine base plan credibility.

# SPIF Design Principles - Guidance

**How It Works:** Effective SPIFs: Specific objective, limited duration, simple mechanics, meaningful but not excessive payout, clear communication, fair measurement.

**Example:** Good SPIF: First 10 reps to close 3+ deals this month get $500 bonus. Clear objective, simple mechanics, limited duration, meaningful but not distorting.

**Best Practices:**
- Tie to specific strategic objective
- Keep duration short (1-3 months)
- Make mechanics simple
- Size appropriately (5-15% of variable)
- Communicate clearly

**Watch Out For:**
- SPIF fatigue from too many
- SPIFs that undermine base plan
- Unclear measurement
- Gaming behaviors

# Sales Equity Compensation

**Definition:** Analysis and benchmarking of equity compensation (RSUs, stock options) for sales roles, increasingly common in technology and high-growth companies.
**Also known as:** equity grants, RSU, stock compensation

**Why It Matters:** Equity is significant part of total comp in tech. Sales roles increasingly receive equity, requiring benchmarking and integration with cash compensation philosophy.

# Sales Equity Compensation - Guidance

**How It Works:** Benchmark equity grant values by role and level. Consider vesting schedules. Analyze equity as part of total target direct compensation. Balance equity with cash in total package.

**Example:** Enterprise AE: $150K base + $150K target variable + $100K equity (4-year vest) = $400K TTDC. Market 50th percentile TTDC is $380K. Positioned slightly above median.

**Best Practices:**
- Include equity in total comp analysis
- Benchmark grant values, not share counts
- Consider vesting and retention effects
- Balance equity vs cash by career stage

**Watch Out For:**
- Equity valuation varies with stock price
- Vesting creates retention handcuffs
- Refresh grants affect perceived value
- Tax implications for employees

# Change Sustainment

**Definition:** Activities and mechanisms to ensure changes become embedded in organizational culture and processes, preventing regression to old behaviors.
**Also known as:** sustaining change, reinforcement, lasting change

**Why It Matters:** Many changes fail not at go-live but afterward when attention moves elsewhere. Sustainment ensures lasting adoption rather than temporary compliance.

# Change Sustainment - Guidance

**How It Works:** Reinforcement mechanisms: Leadership modeling, recognition programs, performance management integration, continued communication, ongoing training, success stories.

**Example:** 6 months post-go-live: Quarterly adoption reviews, manager recognition for team adoption, new hire onboarding includes system training, success stories shared monthly.

**Best Practices:**
- Plan sustainment before go-live
- Integrate into performance management
- Continue communication past go-live
- Recognize adoption champions
- Monitor for regression

**Watch Out For:**
- Attention drift post-go-live
- Manager role model lapses
- New hire training gaps
- Regression without monitoring

# Virginia Wage Laws

**Definition:** Virginia regulations governing wage and commission payments under the Virginia Wage Payment Act.
**Also known as:** VA wage laws, Virginia commission payment

**Why It Matters:** Virginia has specific requirements for wage payment including final pay timing and written notice that differ from neighboring states.

# Virginia Wage Laws - Guidance


**Best Practices:**
- Document commission terms in writing
- Pay on established schedule
- Provide final pay by next payday
- Maintain accurate records

**Watch Out For:**
- Written notice requirements
- Final pay timing
- Penalty exposure
- Recordkeeping requirements

# Virginia Wage Laws - Regulatory Information

**Legal Basis:** Virginia Wage Payment Act (Va. Code Section 40.1-29).

**Requirements:**
- Wages due on regular paydays
- Final wages due next regular payday
- Written notice of wages and pay dates
- Cannot withhold as penalty

**Penalties:** Civil penalties up to $1,000 per violation. Employee may recover wages plus liquidated damages and attorney's fees.

# Georgia Commission Laws

**Definition:** Georgia regulations governing commission payments, which largely defer to federal FLSA and contract law.
**Also known as:** GA commission laws, Georgia wage payment

**Why It Matters:** Georgia is generally employer-friendly without comprehensive wage payment statute, but contractual obligations are enforceable and FLSA applies.

# Georgia Commission Laws - Guidance


**Best Practices:**
- Document commission terms clearly
- Ensure FLSA compliance
- Follow contract terms
- Maintain payment records

**Watch Out For:**
- Lack of state law doesn't eliminate obligations
- FLSA still applies
- Contract terms enforceable
- Atlanta ordinances may apply

# Georgia Commission Laws - Regulatory Information

**Legal Basis:** No comprehensive state wage payment law. FLSA applies. Contract law governs commission agreements.

**Requirements:**
- FLSA minimum wage and overtime rules apply
- Commission agreements contractually enforceable
- No state-mandated final pay timing
- Follow contract terms for payment

**Penalties:** FLSA violations federally enforced. Contract breach in civil court.

# Ireland Commission Requirements

**Definition:** Irish regulations governing commission payments under the Payment of Wages Act and Terms of Employment Act.
**Also known as:** Irish commission law, Ireland employment

**Why It Matters:** Ireland is a common European hub for US multinationals. Understanding local requirements ensures compliance for regional sales teams.

# Ireland Commission Requirements - Guidance


**Best Practices:**
- Provide written terms including commission
- Apply PAYE to commission payments
- Avoid unauthorized deductions
- Consult local counsel for complex plans

**Watch Out For:**
- Written terms requirement
- PAYE on all compensation
- Deduction restrictions
- WRC enforcement

# Ireland Commission Requirements - Regulatory Information

**Legal Basis:** Payment of Wages Act 1991, Terms of Employment (Information) Acts.

**Requirements:**
- Written statement of terms required
- Commission is wages subject to PAYE
- Payment must be in accessible form
- No unauthorized deductions

**Penalties:** WRC complaints, adjudication hearings, compensation awards.

# Spain Commission Requirements

**Definition:** Spanish regulations governing commission payments under the Workers' Statute and collective agreements.
**Also known as:** Spanish commission law, Spain employment

**Why It Matters:** Spain has specific requirements around commercial agents and employee sales roles with strong worker protections.

# Spain Commission Requirements - Guidance


**Best Practices:**
- Document commission in employment contract
- Consider collective agreement requirements
- Distinguish employees from commercial agents
- Budget for social security on variable

**Watch Out For:**
- Collective agreement requirements
- Extra payment obligations
- Commercial agent protections
- Termination compensation

# Spain Commission Requirements - Regulatory Information

**Legal Basis:** Workers' Statute (Estatuto de los Trabajadores), applicable collective agreements, Commercial Agents Act.

**Requirements:**
- Employment contract must specify compensation
- Extra payments (pagas extra) may include commission
- Commercial agents have specific protections
- Social security contributions on all compensation

**Penalties:** Labor court claims, social security enforcement.

# Sales Manager Compensation

**Definition:** Compensation design for sales managers, balancing team performance incentives with individual leadership behaviors.
**Also known as:** manager comp, leadership compensation, manager incentives

**Why It Matters:** Manager compensation shapes leadership behavior. Plans focused only on team results may underweight coaching and development. Balance is critical.

# Sales Manager Compensation - Guidance

**How It Works:** Components typically include: Team rollup (team attainment affects manager pay), Individual component (quota for manager-owned accounts), MBOs (development, coaching, operational metrics).

**Example:** First-line Manager: 70% on team attainment, 20% on personal accounts, 10% on coaching metrics. Pay mix: 60/40 base/variable.

**Best Practices:**
- Weight team outcomes primarily
- Include development and coaching measures
- Align with company management philosophy
- Consider span of control in design

**Watch Out For:**
- Managers who only focus on top reps
- Neglect of development activities
- Cherry-picking accounts
- Conflict with rep interests

# Surrogate Key Management

**Definition:** The use of system-generated unique identifiers to maintain data integrity across compensation systems, independent of source system IDs.
**Also known as:** key management, ID management, reference integrity

**Why It Matters:** Source system IDs change or conflict. Surrogate keys provide stable references that maintain data integrity across systems and time.

# Surrogate Key Management - Guidance

**How It Works:** ICM system generates unique surrogate key for each entity. Cross-reference table maps source IDs to surrogates. All internal references use surrogates. Source ID changes are absorbed in mapping layer.

**Example:** Employee hired, gets HRIS ID 12345 and ICM surrogate key ICM-EMP-00098765. Employee transfers, HRIS creates new ID 12346. ICM adds mapping from 12346 to same surrogate, maintaining history.

**Best Practices:**
- Generate surrogate keys in ICM layer
- Maintain source-to-surrogate mapping
- Use surrogates for all internal references
- Handle source ID changes gracefully

**Watch Out For:**
- Source ID changes breaking references
- Duplicate source records
- Mapping table maintenance
- Key collision prevention

# Integration Error Handling

**Definition:** Strategies for detecting, logging, alerting, and recovering from data integration errors in compensation systems.
**Also known as:** error management, exception handling, integration recovery

**Why It Matters:** Integration errors left uncaught cause calculation errors and payment issues. Robust error handling ensures data quality and enables fast recovery.

# Integration Error Handling - Guidance

**How It Works:** Validate data at ingestion. Log errors with full context. Route to error queue for review. Alert appropriate teams. Provide remediation tools. Track error patterns for prevention.

**Example:** Transaction fails validation (missing account owner). Error logged with transaction ID, failure reason, source details. Alert sent to sales ops. Transaction held in error queue. Ops corrects and resubmits.

**Best Practices:**
- Validate early in pipeline
- Log full context for troubleshooting
- Alert appropriate teams
- Provide self-service remediation
- Track patterns for prevention

**Watch Out For:**
- Silent failures
- Insufficient context in logs
- Alert fatigue
- Error queue backlog

# Manager Adoption Metrics

**Definition:** Specific metrics tracking sales manager engagement with compensation systems, distinct from rep-level adoption.
**Also known as:** manager usage, leadership adoption, manager engagement

**Why It Matters:** Manager adoption influences rep adoption and enables effective coaching. Managers who don't use the system can't coach reps on their compensation.

# Manager Adoption Metrics - Guidance

**How It Works:** Track: Team dashboard views, report generation, approval turnaround, coaching conversation frequency, system-based performance reviews.

**Example:** Manager adoption dashboard: 75% viewed team dashboard this month (target 90%), 60% generated custom reports, average approval turnaround 4 hours (target <8 hours).

**Best Practices:**
- Track manager-specific behaviors
- Include in manager expectations
- Provide manager-focused training
- Connect to coaching effectiveness
- Recognize high-adopting managers

**Watch Out For:**
- Managers delegating system use
- Adoption without understanding
- Time constraints limiting engagement
- Different manager personas

# Multi-Language Plan Documents

**Definition:** Requirements and best practices for providing compensation plan documents in languages spoken by the sales population.
**Also known as:** translated documents, localized plans, language requirements

**Why It Matters:** Employees should understand their compensation terms. Many jurisdictions require documents in local language. English-only may not constitute valid notice.

# Multi-Language Plan Documents - Guidance

**How It Works:** Identify language requirements by jurisdiction. Translate core plan documents. Determine controlling language for disputes. Maintain version control across translations.

**Example:** Global company with EMEA sales: English master document, translated to German, French, Spanish. German version required by German law. Controlling language clause specifies English for disputes.

**Best Practices:**
- Identify legal translation requirements
- Use professional translation services
- Specify controlling language
- Maintain consistent versions
- Consider local legal review

**Watch Out For:**
- Legal requirements for local language
- Translation quality and accuracy
- Version control across languages
- Controlling language for disputes

# Win Rate vs Volume Trade-offs

**Definition:** The compensation design decision about whether to incentivize deal selectivity (higher win rates) or deal volume (more at-bats).
**Also known as:** selectivity vs volume, quality vs quantity

**Why It Matters:** Different business strategies require different seller behaviors. Comp design can encourage selectivity or volume, impacting pipeline quality and conversion.

# Win Rate vs Volume Trade-offs - Guidance

**How It Works:** Volume focus: Pay on activity metrics, low thresholds, linear earning. Selectivity focus: Pay on closed deals only, quality gates, efficiency metrics like win rate or deal margin.

**Example:** High-volume transactional sale: Pay on meetings booked encourages activity. Complex enterprise sale: Pay only on closed-won with margin gates encourages selectivity and deal quality.

**Best Practices:**
- Align with sales motion and deal complexity
- Consider cost of poor quality deals
- Balance volume and selectivity in multi-measure plans
- Measure what you want to optimize

**Watch Out For:**
- Volume focus creates poor pipeline
- Selectivity focus reduces activity
- Conflicting signals confuse reps
- Measure gaming

# ICM Analytics Capabilities

**Definition:** The native analytics and reporting capabilities of incentive compensation platforms, from basic statements to advanced predictive analytics.
**Also known as:** comp analytics, ICM reporting, platform analytics

**Why It Matters:** Analytics capabilities vary widely across platforms. Understanding native capabilities helps determine what can be done in-platform vs requiring external BI tools.

# ICM Analytics Capabilities - Guidance

**How It Works:** Capability spectrum: Basic (statements, summary reports) → Standard (dashboards, drill-down, exports) → Advanced (predictive, what-if, ML-powered insights).

**Example:** Platform comparison: Vendor A offers basic statements only. Vendor B adds self-service dashboards. Vendor C provides predictive payout forecasting and plan optimization recommendations.

**Best Practices:**
- Assess analytics needs before platform selection
- Leverage native capabilities before building external
- Plan for analytics evolution
- Consider user self-service needs

**Watch Out For:**
- Over-estimating native capabilities
- Under-utilizing available features
- Custom report maintenance burden
- Performance with large data

# ICM Vendor Selection

**Definition:** The structured process of evaluating and selecting an incentive compensation management platform based on requirements and fit.
**Also known as:** platform selection, RFP process, vendor evaluation

**Why It Matters:** Platform choice impacts implementation success, ongoing operations, and long-term total cost. Structured evaluation ensures the right fit for organizational needs.

# ICM Vendor Selection - Guidance

**How It Works:** Define requirements. Identify candidates. Issue RFI/RFP. Conduct demonstrations. Evaluate against criteria. Check references. Negotiate and select. Document decision.

**Example:** Selection process: Month 1 - Requirements gathering. Month 2 - RFI to 8 vendors. Month 3 - Shortlist to 3, detailed demos. Month 4 - Reference checks, negotiation. Month 5 - Selection and contracting.

**Best Practices:**
- Define requirements before evaluating
- Include all stakeholder perspectives
- Use structured scoring criteria
- Check references thoroughly
- Consider total cost of ownership

**Watch Out For:**
- Demo-driven decisions vs requirements fit
- Hidden implementation costs
- Reference bias
- Contract term lock-in

# Arizona Commission Laws

**Definition:** Arizona regulations governing wage and commission payments under Arizona Revised Statutes.
**Also known as:** AZ wage laws, Arizona payment timing

**Why It Matters:** Arizona has specific requirements including semi-monthly payment requirements and final pay timing that employers must follow.

# Arizona Commission Laws - Guidance


**Best Practices:**
- Pay at least semi-monthly
- Provide final pay within 7 days
- Document wage terms in writing
- Maintain payment records

**Watch Out For:**
- Semi-monthly payment requirement
- Final pay timing
- Triple damages exposure
- Written notice requirement

# Arizona Commission Laws - Regulatory Information

**Legal Basis:** Arizona Revised Statutes Section 23-350 et seq.

**Requirements:**
- Wages must be paid at least semi-monthly
- Final wages due within 7 working days or next payday
- Written notice of wage rates
- Cannot withhold as penalty

**Penalties:** Triple damages available. Civil penalties.

# Quota Relief Policies

**Definition:** Policies governing when and how quotas are adjusted for circumstances outside rep control, such as territory changes, product issues, or market disruptions.
**Also known as:** quota adjustment, quota exceptions, relief policies

**Why It Matters:** Rigid quotas in the face of uncontrollable factors demotivate reps and feel unfair. Structured relief policies maintain motivation while preventing gaming.

# Quota Relief Policies - Guidance

**How It Works:** Define eligible circumstances. Establish approval process. Calculate adjustment methodology. Document and communicate. Track relief granted for analysis.

**Example:** Quota relief policy: Territory reduction >20% triggers proportional quota reduction. Product launch delay >60 days: quota reduced for affected product line. Requires VP approval with documentation.

**Best Practices:**
- Define clear eligibility criteria
- Establish approval authority
- Use consistent calculation methodology
- Document all relief granted
- Analyze relief patterns for planning

**Watch Out For:**
- Inconsistent application
- Gaming through territory changes
- Relief without documentation
- Excessive relief eroding quotas

# Commission Automation Levels

**Definition:** The spectrum of automation in commission processing, from fully manual spreadsheet processes to fully automated end-to-end systems.
**Also known as:** automation maturity, manual vs automated

**Why It Matters:** Understanding current automation level helps identify improvement opportunities. Higher automation reduces errors and frees resources for analysis.

# Commission Automation Levels - Guidance

**How It Works:** Maturity levels: Manual (spreadsheets) → Semi-automated (data feeds + spreadsheet calc) → System-calculated (ICM platform) → Integrated (auto-feed to payroll) → Intelligent (predictive, self-optimizing).

**Example:** Assessment: Data extraction is automated, calculation is in spreadsheets, payment file is manual. Opportunity: Implement ICM platform for calculation and payment automation.

**Best Practices:**
- Assess current automation honestly
- Prioritize high-value automation opportunities
- Consider total cost of current state
- Plan for incremental improvement

**Watch Out For:**
- Underestimating spreadsheet maintenance
- Over-automating stable processes
- Integration complexity underestimated
- Change management for automation

# Blended Learning Approach

**Definition:** Training approach combining multiple delivery methods (instructor-led, e-learning, simulation, coaching) to optimize learning outcomes and efficiency.
**Also known as:** hybrid training, multi-modal learning

**Why It Matters:** Different content and audiences are best served by different methods. Blended approach maximizes learning while respecting time and geographic constraints.

# Blended Learning Approach - Guidance

**How It Works:** Identify learning objectives. Match objectives to best delivery methods. Sequence learning activities. Provide reinforcement across modalities. Track progress across all channels.

**Example:** Admin training blend: Pre-work e-learning on concepts → Live workshop for hands-on practice → Simulation for certification → Coaching during hypercare → Microlearning for ongoing reference.

**Best Practices:**
- Match method to learning objective
- Sequence from knowledge to application
- Provide multiple reinforcement touchpoints
- Accommodate different learning preferences
- Track completion across modalities

**Watch Out For:**
- Overwhelming with too many channels
- Gaps between modalities
- Tracking complexity
- Inconsistent content across channels

# Commission and Wrongful Termination

**Definition:** Legal issues arising when termination timing appears designed to avoid paying commissions, potentially creating wrongful termination or breach of contract claims.
**Also known as:** termination timing, commission acceleration

**Why It Matters:** Termination just before large commission payment can create legal exposure for bad faith, even in at-will employment situations.

# Commission and Wrongful Termination - Guidance


**Example:** Rep terminated one week before $500K deal closes that they worked on for 6 months. Circumstances suggest termination timed to avoid commission. Potential bad faith claim regardless of at-will status.

**Best Practices:**
- Document termination reasons thoroughly
- Consider commission timing in termination decisions
- Pay earned commissions regardless of timing
- Consult legal for high-stakes terminations

**Watch Out For:**
- Termination timing near large commissions
- Pattern of pre-commission terminations
- Documentation gaps
- Jurisdiction-specific protections

# Commission and Wrongful Termination - Regulatory Information

**Legal Basis:** Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, state wage laws, contract law.

**Requirements:**
- Good faith dealing in commission relationships
- Cannot terminate solely to avoid payment
- Post-termination commission rights per agreement
- State laws may mandate payment of earned commission

**Penalties:** Contract damages, potential tort damages for bad faith, wage claim penalties.

# Compensation Cost Forecasting

**Definition:** Projecting future compensation costs based on plan design, quota assumptions, and performance forecasts to inform budgeting and financial planning.
**Also known as:** cost projection, budget forecasting, accrual forecasting

**Why It Matters:** Finance requires accurate cost projections for budgeting and accruals. Sales leadership needs visibility into total compensation spend.

# Compensation Cost Forecasting - Guidance

**How It Works:** Model inputs: Plan mechanics, headcount, quota coverage, performance assumptions. Apply plan rules to projected performance. Generate cost by period, segment, plan. Sensitivity analysis for scenarios.

**Example:** FY2027 forecast: 100 reps × $150K OTE × 1.05 average attainment = $15.75M. Sensitivity: If attainment is 1.15, cost increases to $17.25M. Budget buffer needed.

**Best Practices:**
- Base on realistic performance assumptions
- Include headcount and timing effects
- Model multiple scenarios
- Update forecasts monthly
- Reconcile actual to forecast

**Watch Out For:**
- Overly optimistic assumptions
- Missing headcount effects
- Quota quality impact
- Accelerator leverage underestimated

# SSO and MFA for ICM

**Definition:** Security integration patterns for ICM systems including Single Sign-On (SSO) for unified access and Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for enhanced security.
**Also known as:** single sign-on, multi-factor authentication, ICM security

**Why It Matters:** ICM systems contain sensitive compensation data. SSO improves user experience while MFA protects against unauthorized access. Both are often required for SOX compliance.

# SSO and MFA for ICM - Guidance

**How It Works:** SSO: SAML or OIDC integration with identity provider (Okta, Azure AD). Users authenticate once for access to all systems. MFA: Second factor (push notification, OTP, hardware key) required for access.

**Example:** Implementation: Okta as IdP, SAML integration with Xactly. Users authenticate via Okta with MFA. Session established for all integrated applications including ICM.

**Best Practices:**
- Implement SSO for user experience
- Require MFA for sensitive access
- Configure session timeouts appropriately
- Audit authentication logs
- Plan for IdP failover

**Watch Out For:**
- SSO single point of failure
- MFA user experience friction
- Service account authentication
- Session management complexity

# Day One Readiness

**Definition:** The comprehensive assessment that all components are ready for users to begin using the compensation system on day one.
**Also known as:** go-live readiness, launch readiness, day 1 checklist

**Why It Matters:** Day one problems undermine confidence and adoption. Thorough readiness assessment prevents embarrassing failures and ensures positive first impressions.

# Day One Readiness - Guidance

**How It Works:** Readiness dimensions: Technical (system, data, integrations), Operational (support, documentation, training complete), Organizational (communication done, users enabled), Contingency (rollback tested, escalation defined).

**Example:** Day one readiness gate: Technical sign-off ✓, UAT complete ✓, Training 95% complete ✓, Communications sent ✓, Support staffed ✓, Rollback tested ✓. Proceed to go-live.

**Best Practices:**
- Define readiness criteria early
- Track leading indicators
- Require sign-offs from all owners
- Have clear go/no-go decision authority
- Document readiness assessment

**Watch Out For:**
- Pressure to go live despite gaps
- Missing readiness dimensions
- Last-minute discoveries
- Unclear decision authority

# Dodd-Frank Compensation Rules

**Definition:** Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform Act provisions affecting executive and sales compensation in financial services, including clawback and disclosure requirements.
**Also known as:** Dodd-Frank, financial services compensation

**Why It Matters:** Financial services companies face additional compensation regulations. Sales roles in banks and broker-dealers may be subject to specific requirements.

# Dodd-Frank Compensation Rules - Guidance


**Best Practices:**
- Identify applicable Dodd-Frank provisions
- Implement compliant clawback policies
- Prepare required disclosures
- Monitor regulatory guidance evolution

**Watch Out For:**
- Different requirements by financial institution type
- Evolving agency implementation
- Intersection with SEC rules
- State law overlay

# Dodd-Frank Compensation Rules - Regulatory Information

**Legal Basis:** Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010), implementing agency rules.

**Requirements:**
- Clawback policies for financial institutions
- Say-on-pay shareholder votes
- Pay ratio disclosure
- Incentive-based compensation restrictions for covered financial institutions

**Penalties:** Regulatory enforcement, proxy disclosure failures, shareholder activism.

# Commitment Devices in Compensation

**Definition:** Compensation design elements that encourage reps to commit to performance targets, leveraging the psychological power of stated commitments.
**Also known as:** performance commitments, self-commitment, goal commitment

**Why It Matters:** People work harder toward goals they've publicly committed to. Compensation design can incorporate commitment mechanisms to enhance motivation.

# Commitment Devices in Compensation - Guidance

**How It Works:** Mechanisms: Rep-selected targets, public goal statements, stretch goal selection with upside, team commitments. Commitment increases effort and follow-through.

**Example:** Rep selects stretch tier: Standard quota or +10% stretch with 25% additional commission if achieved. Public selection creates commitment. 70% of stretch-selectors achieve, vs 50% predicted by historical performance.

**Best Practices:**
- Offer meaningful choice in targets
- Make commitments visible
- Provide appropriate upside for stretch
- Avoid punishing stretch failures
- Track commitment vs achievement

**Watch Out For:**
- Risk aversion limiting stretch selection
- Sandbagging on standard tier
- Commitment without follow-through resources
- Fairness perceptions of different tiers

# Compensation Data Governance

**Definition:** The framework of policies, roles, and processes that ensure compensation data is accurate, secure, and properly managed across its lifecycle.
**Also known as:** data governance, data ownership, data stewardship

**Why It Matters:** Poor data governance leads to calculation errors, compliance issues, and security breaches. Formal governance ensures data quality and appropriate access.

# Compensation Data Governance - Guidance

**How It Works:** Components: Data ownership (who is accountable), stewardship (who maintains), policies (how data is handled), quality standards (what is acceptable), access controls (who can see/change).

**Example:** Governance framework: HR owns employee data, Sales Ops owns transaction data, Finance owns payment data. Each owner ensures quality and approves access. Quarterly data quality reviews.

**Best Practices:**
- Assign clear data ownership
- Define data quality standards
- Implement access controls
- Conduct regular quality reviews
- Document data lineage

**Watch Out For:**
- Unclear ownership creates gaps
- Quality standards not enforced
- Access creep over time
- Governance overhead

# Implementation Partner Selection

**Definition:** The process of evaluating and selecting systems integrators or consulting partners to assist with compensation system implementation.
**Also known as:** SI selection, consultant selection, partner evaluation

**Why It Matters:** Implementation partner capability significantly impacts project success. Right partner brings expertise, accelerates delivery, and reduces risk.

# Implementation Partner Selection - Guidance

**How It Works:** Define needs (implementation, change management, training). Identify candidates. Evaluate credentials and references. Assess team fit and availability. Negotiate and contract.

**Example:** Partner selection: Shortlist 3 vendors with Xactly expertise. Evaluate on: relevant experience, proposed team, methodology, references, cost. Select partner with strongest industry experience and available senior resources.

**Best Practices:**
- Define specific needs before selecting
- Evaluate proposed team, not just firm
- Check references thoroughly
- Negotiate team commitment
- Define success metrics in contract

**Watch Out For:**
- Senior team at sale, junior at delivery
- Lack of specific platform experience
- Overpromising capabilities
- Contract gaps on deliverables

# Mexico Commission Requirements

**Definition:** Mexican regulations governing commission payments under the Federal Labor Law and related requirements including profit sharing.
**Also known as:** Mexican commission law, Mexico labor law

**Why It Matters:** Mexico has unique requirements including mandatory profit sharing that affects total compensation design and cost.

# Mexico Commission Requirements - Guidance


**Best Practices:**
- Include commission in integrated salary calculations
- Budget for aguinaldo on variable
- Plan for PTU obligations
- Structure commission clearly in employment agreement

**Watch Out For:**
- Commission affects all benefit calculations
- PTU is 10% of pre-tax profits to employees
- Social security base affected
- Termination indemnity includes commission

# Mexico Commission Requirements - Regulatory Information

**Legal Basis:** Federal Labor Law (Ley Federal del Trabajo), Mexican Constitution Article 123.

**Requirements:**
- Commission is part of integrated salary for benefits
- Christmas bonus (Aguinaldo) calculated on salary including commission
- Profit sharing (PTU) is mandatory
- Social security contributions on all compensation

**Penalties:** Labor court claims (Juntas de Conciliación), IMSS enforcement for social security.

# Team vs Individual Incentives

**Definition:** The design decision about how to balance incentives based on individual performance versus team or group outcomes.
**Also known as:** team compensation, individual vs team, collaborative incentives

**Why It Matters:** Team incentives encourage collaboration but may demotivate top performers. Individual incentives drive personal performance but may discourage teamwork.

# Team vs Individual Incentives - Guidance

**How It Works:** Spectrum from 100% individual to 100% team. Most plans blend: individual quota performance plus team modifier, or team pool distributed by individual contribution.

**Example:** Blended approach: 70% on individual quota attainment, 30% on team revenue goal. Individual performance drives majority, team component encourages collaboration and knowledge sharing.

**Best Practices:**
- Match to sales motion requirements
- Consider controllability of team outcome
- Balance collaboration vs competition
- Ensure team definition makes sense
- Communicate rationale for blend

**Watch Out For:**
- Free-rider problem with high team component
- Top performer resentment of team drag
- Team definition that doesn't match reality
- Measurement complexity
